trans-unit.source: Split
trans-unit.target: Split

trans-unit.source: Partitions the rows of a dataset into two distinct sets
trans-unit.target: Partitions the rows of a dataset into two distinct sets

trans-unit.source: Category: <legacyLink xlink:href="73A66797-D6E4-48A1-98C1-2D764EC5D2CD" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Data Transformation / Sample and Split</legacyLink>
trans-unit.target: Category: <legacyLink xlink:href="73A66797-D6E4-48A1-98C1-2D764EC5D2CD" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Data Transformation / Sample and Split</legacyLink>

trans-unit.source: Module Overview
trans-unit.target: Module Overview

trans-unit.source: You can use the <ui>Split</ui> module to divide a dataset into two distinct sets.
trans-unit.target: You can use the <ui>Split</ui> module to divide a dataset into two distinct sets.

trans-unit.source: Depending on your goal and the type of data, you can use any of these splitting modes:
trans-unit.target: Depending on your goal and the type of data, you can use any of these splitting modes:

trans-unit.source: Split Rows
trans-unit.target: Split Rows

trans-unit.source: Use this option to divide the dataset into two datasets.
trans-unit.target: Use this option to divide the dataset into two datasets.

trans-unit.source: You can randomize the rows that are assigned to each output dataset, or use stratified sampling.
trans-unit.target: You can randomize the rows that are assigned to each output dataset, or use stratified sampling.

trans-unit.source: By default, the <ui>Split</ui> module splits a dataset into two equal parts; however, you can change the percentage of data in each split.
trans-unit.target: By default, the <ui>Split</ui> module splits a dataset into two equal parts; however, you can change the percentage of data in each split.

trans-unit.source: Recommender Split
trans-unit.target: Recommender Split

trans-unit.source: This option makes it easy to apportion your data into training and testing sets for use in recommender systems.
trans-unit.target: This option makes it easy to apportion your data into training and testing sets for use in recommender systems.

trans-unit.source: If you are splitting complex sets of data for a recommendation model, use this mode.
trans-unit.target: If you are splitting complex sets of data for a recommendation model, use this mode.

trans-unit.source: It can ensure that user-item pairs (and optionally ratings) are evenly divided into training and test sets.
trans-unit.target: It can ensure that user-item pairs (and optionally ratings) are evenly divided into training and test sets.

trans-unit.source: See the <legacyLink xlink:href="#bkmk_RecommenderSplit" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Recommender split</legacyLink> section for details.
trans-unit.target: See the <legacyLink xlink:href="#bkmk_RecommenderSplit" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Recommender split</legacyLink> section for details.

trans-unit.source: Regular Expression
trans-unit.target: Regular Expression

trans-unit.source: Use <newTerm>regular expressions</newTerm> when you want to divide your dataset by testing a single column for a value from a regular expression.
trans-unit.target: Use <newTerm>regular expressions</newTerm> when you want to divide your dataset by testing a single column for a value from a regular expression.

trans-unit.source: For example, you could check for the presence of a product name in a text field and divide the dataset into product mentions versus other text.
trans-unit.target: For example, you could check for the presence of a product name in a text field and divide the dataset into product mentions versus other text.

trans-unit.source: Relative Expression
trans-unit.target: Relative Expression

trans-unit.source: Use <newTerm>relative expressions</newTerm> if you want to apply a condition to a numeric field.
trans-unit.target: Use <newTerm>relative expressions</newTerm> if you want to apply a condition to a numeric field.

trans-unit.source: For example, you might separate items by a cost field, or separate patients by an age range.
trans-unit.target: For example, you might separate items by a cost field, or separate patients by an age range.

trans-unit.source: Compared to the <link xlink:href="a8726e34-1b3e-4515-b59a-3e4a475654b8" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Partition and Sample</link> module, <ui>Split</ui> has these requirements:
trans-unit.target: Compared to the <link xlink:href="a8726e34-1b3e-4515-b59a-3e4a475654b8" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Partition and Sample</link> module, <ui>Split</ui> has these requirements:

trans-unit.source: You can create only two sets, and those sets must be exclusive.
trans-unit.target: You can create only two sets, and those sets must be exclusive.

trans-unit.source: You can’t exclude unwanted data or filter out some rows and keep others because <ui>Split</ui> always keeps the complete set of data.
trans-unit.target: You can’t exclude unwanted data or filter out some rows and keep others because <ui>Split</ui> always keeps the complete set of data.

trans-unit.source: However, by chaining multiple <ui>Split</ui> modules, you can partition data in many ways.
trans-unit.target: However, by chaining multiple <ui>Split</ui> modules, you can partition data in many ways.

trans-unit.source: How to Configure Split
trans-unit.target: How to Configure Split

trans-unit.source: Add the <ui>Split</ui> module to your experiment, and connect it as input to the dataset you want to split.
trans-unit.target: Add the <ui>Split</ui> module to your experiment, and connect it as input to the dataset you want to split.

trans-unit.source: You specify the condition by which to divide the dataset by choosing a <ui>Splitting mode</ui>.
trans-unit.target: You specify the condition by which to divide the dataset by choosing a <ui>Splitting mode</ui>.

trans-unit.source: Based on the splitting mode you select, there are multiple options for defining the criteria to use when dividing the dataset.
trans-unit.target: Based on the splitting mode you select, there are multiple options for defining the criteria to use when dividing the dataset.

trans-unit.source: See the <legacyLink xlink:href="#bkmk_Options" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Options</legacyLink> section for details.
trans-unit.target: See the <legacyLink xlink:href="#bkmk_Options" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Options</legacyLink> section for details.

trans-unit.source: Split Rows Examples
trans-unit.target: Split Rows Examples

trans-unit.source: The following examples demonstrate how to perform simple splits using <ui>Split Rows</ui> mode:
trans-unit.target: The following examples demonstrate how to perform simple splits using <ui>Split Rows</ui> mode:

trans-unit.source: To split a dataset into two equal parts, just add the <ui>Split</ui> module after the dataset without no other changes.
trans-unit.target: To split a dataset into two equal parts, just add the <ui>Split</ui> module after the dataset without no other changes.

trans-unit.source: By default, the module splits the dataset in two equal parts.
trans-unit.target: By default, the module splits the dataset in two equal parts.

trans-unit.source: For data with an odd number of rows, the second output gets the remainder.
trans-unit.target: For data with an odd number of rows, the second output gets the remainder.

trans-unit.source: Assuming you want to split a dataset into two parts, with a third of the data used for training and the remainder for testing or additional splits.
trans-unit.target: Assuming you want to split a dataset into two parts, with a third of the data used for training and the remainder for testing or additional splits.

trans-unit.source: Add a <ui>Split</ui> module, and set the <ui>Fraction of rows in the first output</ui> to 0.33.
trans-unit.target: Add a <ui>Split</ui> module, and set the <ui>Fraction of rows in the first output</ui> to 0.33.

trans-unit.source: The second output contains the remaining two-thirds.
trans-unit.target: The second output contains the remaining two-thirds.

trans-unit.source: Recommender Split Examples
trans-unit.target: Recommender Split Examples

trans-unit.source: For examples of how to divide a set of ratings and features used for training or testing a recommendation model, we recommend that you review the walkthrough provided with this sample experiment in the <externalLink><linkText>Model Gallery</linkText><linkUri>http://gallery.azureml.net/</linkUri></externalLink>: <externalLink><linkText>Movie Recommendation</linkText><linkUri>http://gallery.azureml.net/Experiment/3a02931f94114f47b4512dd9179b515e?share=1</linkUri></externalLink>
trans-unit.target: For examples of how to divide a set of ratings and features used for training or testing a recommendation model, we recommend that you review the walkthrough provided with this sample experiment in the <externalLink><linkText>Model Gallery</linkText><linkUri>http://gallery.azureml.net/</linkUri></externalLink>: <externalLink><linkText>Movie Recommendation</linkText><linkUri>http://gallery.azureml.net/Experiment/3a02931f94114f47b4512dd9179b515e?share=1</linkUri></externalLink>

trans-unit.source: Regular Expression Examples
trans-unit.target: Regular Expression Examples

trans-unit.source: The following examples demonstrate how to divide a dataset using <legacyItalic><ui>Regular Expression</ui></legacyItalic> mode:
trans-unit.target: The following examples demonstrate how to divide a dataset using <legacyItalic><ui>Regular Expression</ui></legacyItalic> mode:

trans-unit.source: Using regular expressions to divide the dataset is useful when you need to divide your dataset based on a known value, or part of a value.
trans-unit.target: Using regular expressions to divide the dataset is useful when you need to divide your dataset based on a known value, or part of a value.

trans-unit.source: You can also use it for a variety of preprocessing and filtering tasks.
trans-unit.target: You can also use it for a variety of preprocessing and filtering tasks.

trans-unit.source: Filter on all rows that contain the text "Gryphon" by applying the following regular expression to a string column:
trans-unit.target: Filter on all rows that contain the text "Gryphon" by applying the following regular expression to a string column:

trans-unit.source: In this example, the substring can be found in any position within the column.
trans-unit.target: In this example, the substring can be found in any position within the column.

trans-unit.source: The match is case-sensitive.
trans-unit.target: The match is case-sensitive.

trans-unit.source: Separate the dataset based on the second column of the dataset, denoted here by the index value of 1.
trans-unit.target: Separate the dataset based on the second column of the dataset, denoted here by the index value of 1.

trans-unit.source: The first result dataset will contains all rows where the index column begins with one of these characters: a, b, c, d, e, f:
trans-unit.target: The first result dataset will contains all rows where the index column begins with one of these characters: a, b, c, d, e, f:

trans-unit.source: Note that the regular expression match is case-sensitive.
trans-unit.target: Note that the regular expression match is case-sensitive.

trans-unit.source: Assume you want to divide some server log data into two categories for analysis: connections behind the firewall and connections with IP addresses outside the firewall.
trans-unit.target: Assume you want to divide some server log data into two categories for analysis: connections behind the firewall and connections with IP addresses outside the firewall.

trans-unit.source: You can use the following regular expression on the IP_Address field (which is of type string) to put into the first output all addresses that begin with “10.”
trans-unit.target: You can use the following regular expression on the IP_Address field (which is of type string) to put into the first output all addresses that begin with “10.”

trans-unit.source: Relative Expression Examples
trans-unit.target: Relative Expression Examples

trans-unit.source: Use this mode to create an expression that acts as a filter on a column of numerical values.
trans-unit.target: Use this mode to create an expression that acts as a filter on a column of numerical values.

trans-unit.source: The following examples demonstrate how to divide a dataset using <legacyItalic><ui>Relative Expression</ui></legacyItalic> mode:
trans-unit.target: The following examples demonstrate how to divide a dataset using <legacyItalic><ui>Relative Expression</ui></legacyItalic> mode:

trans-unit.source: A common scenario is to divide a dataset by years.
trans-unit.target: A common scenario is to divide a dataset by years.

trans-unit.source: The following expression shows how to selects all rows where the values in the column <legacyBold>Year</legacyBold> are greater than 2010.
trans-unit.target: The following expression shows how to selects all rows where the values in the column <legacyBold>Year</legacyBold> are greater than 2010.

trans-unit.source: The following expression demonstrates how you can use the column index to select all rows in the first column of the dataset that contain values less than or equal to 30, but not equal to 20.
trans-unit.target: The following expression demonstrates how you can use the column index to select all rows in the first column of the dataset that contain values less than or equal to 30, but not equal to 20.

trans-unit.source: Suppose you want to split a table of log data, to group queries that run too long.
trans-unit.target: Suppose you want to split a table of log data, to group queries that run too long.

trans-unit.source: You could use the following relative expression to put in one dataset the queries that ran over 1 minute, and then use another instance of <ui>Split</ui> on the right-hand output to extract another set of queries with response times under one minute but more than 30 seconds.
trans-unit.target: You could use the following relative expression to put in one dataset the queries that ran over 1 minute, and then use another instance of <ui>Split</ui> on the right-hand output to extract another set of queries with response times under one minute but more than 30 seconds.

trans-unit.source: Options
trans-unit.target: Options

trans-unit.source: Splitting mode
trans-unit.target: Splitting mode

trans-unit.source: Choose the splitting mode based on the type of dataset you are splitting, and the condition to use when dividing the data.
trans-unit.target: Choose the splitting mode based on the type of dataset you are splitting, and the condition to use when dividing the data.

trans-unit.source: <legacyItalic><ui>Split Rows</ui></legacyItalic>: Choose this mode when you just want to divide the dataset in two parts by a percentage.
trans-unit.target: <legacyItalic><ui>Split Rows</ui></legacyItalic>: Choose this mode when you just want to divide the dataset in two parts by a percentage.

trans-unit.source: <legacyItalic><ui>Recommender split</ui></legacyItalic>: Always select this option when preparing data for training or testing a recommendation model.
trans-unit.target: <legacyItalic><ui>Recommender split</ui></legacyItalic>: Always select this option when preparing data for training or testing a recommendation model.

trans-unit.source: <legacyItalic><ui>Regular Expression</ui></legacyItalic>: Choose this mode if you want to specify a condition that operates on categorical data, using a regular expression.
trans-unit.target: <legacyItalic><ui>Regular Expression</ui></legacyItalic>: Choose this mode if you want to specify a condition that operates on categorical data, using a regular expression.

trans-unit.source: <legacyItalic><ui>Relative Expression</ui></legacyItalic>: Choose this mode if you want to specify a condition that operates on numerical data.
trans-unit.target: <legacyItalic><ui>Relative Expression</ui></legacyItalic>: Choose this mode if you want to specify a condition that operates on numerical data.

trans-unit.source: Split Rows Options
trans-unit.target: Split Rows Options

trans-unit.source: Use the following parameters to control the way the dataset is split:
trans-unit.target: Use the following parameters to control the way the dataset is split:

trans-unit.source: Fraction of rows in the first output dataset
trans-unit.target: Fraction of rows in the first output dataset

trans-unit.source: The ratio should be typed as a decimal number between 0 and 1 to represent the percentage of rows sent to the first output dataset.
trans-unit.target: The ratio should be typed as a decimal number between 0 and 1 to represent the percentage of rows sent to the first output dataset.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you type 0.75 as the value, the dataset would be split by using a 75:25 ratio, with 75% of the rows sent to the first output dataset, and 25% sent to the second output dataset.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you type 0.75 as the value, the dataset would be split by using a 75:25 ratio, with 75% of the rows sent to the first output dataset, and 25% sent to the second output dataset.

trans-unit.source: Randomized split
trans-unit.target: Randomized split

trans-unit.source: Select this option to divide the dataset by using a random split.
trans-unit.target: Select this option to divide the dataset by using a random split.

trans-unit.source: This is the preferred option when creating training and test datasets.
trans-unit.target: This is the preferred option when creating training and test datasets.

trans-unit.source: If you need to repeat the results of a split operation, you should specify a <legacyBold>seed</legacyBold> for the random number generator.
trans-unit.target: If you need to repeat the results of a split operation, you should specify a <legacyBold>seed</legacyBold> for the random number generator.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise the random seed is set by default to 0, which means the initial seed value is obtained from the system clock.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise the random seed is set by default to 0, which means the initial seed value is obtained from the system clock.

trans-unit.source: As a result, the distribution of data might be slightly different each time you perform a split.
trans-unit.target: As a result, the distribution of data might be slightly different each time you perform a split.

trans-unit.source: Random Seed
trans-unit.target: Random Seed

trans-unit.source: Type a non-negative integer value to initialize the pseudorandom sequence of instances to be used.
trans-unit.target: Type a non-negative integer value to initialize the pseudorandom sequence of instances to be used.

trans-unit.source: Specifying a seed makes the results generally reproducible.
trans-unit.target: Specifying a seed makes the results generally reproducible.

trans-unit.source: If you use the default value of 0, a seed value is generated based on the system clock.
trans-unit.target: If you use the default value of 0, a seed value is generated based on the system clock.

trans-unit.source: This default seed is used in all modules that generate random numbers.
trans-unit.target: This default seed is used in all modules that generate random numbers.

trans-unit.source: Stratified split
trans-unit.target: Stratified split

trans-unit.source: Set this option to True to ensure that the two output datasets contain a representative sample of the value in the <newTerm>strata column</newTerm> or <newTerm>stratification key column</newTerm>.
trans-unit.target: Set this option to True to ensure that the two output datasets contain a representative sample of the value in the <newTerm>strata column</newTerm> or <newTerm>stratification key column</newTerm>.

trans-unit.source: You can then select which column has the values to stratify on.
trans-unit.target: You can then select which column has the values to stratify on.

trans-unit.source: With stratified sampling, the data is divided in such a way that a percentage of each target column value is put in each output dataset.
trans-unit.target: With stratified sampling, the data is divided in such a way that a percentage of each target column value is put in each output dataset.

trans-unit.source: This option is useful if the column you choose as the strata has categories that should be balanced.
trans-unit.target: This option is useful if the column you choose as the strata has categories that should be balanced.

trans-unit.source: For example, you might want to balance by income, gender, etc.
trans-unit.target: For example, you might want to balance by income, gender, etc.

trans-unit.source: To use stratified sampling, the strata column must contain nominal or categorical data.
trans-unit.target: To use stratified sampling, the strata column must contain nominal or categorical data.

trans-unit.source: If the strata column you specify has continuous numeric data, an error message appears.
trans-unit.target: If the strata column you specify has continuous numeric data, an error message appears.

trans-unit.source: If your strata column has too many unique values, the column is not a good candidate for splitting over strata.
trans-unit.target: If your strata column has too many unique values, the column is not a good candidate for splitting over strata.

trans-unit.source: Recommender Split Options
trans-unit.target: Recommender Split Options

trans-unit.source: When you split the recommender input datasets, the module returns two datasets—a training set and a test set.
trans-unit.target: When you split the recommender input datasets, the module returns two datasets—a training set and a test set.

trans-unit.source: If the input dataset contains any extra data per instance (such as ratings), it is preserved in the output.
trans-unit.target: If the input dataset contains any extra data per instance (such as ratings), it is preserved in the output.

trans-unit.source: The following options apply only to data that is used in recommendation models.
trans-unit.target: The following options apply only to data that is used in recommendation models.

trans-unit.source: Fraction of training only users
trans-unit.target: Fraction of training only users

trans-unit.source: You can specify that some fraction of users be assigned only to the training data set, which means that they would never be used to test the model.
trans-unit.target: You can specify that some fraction of users be assigned only to the training data set, which means that they would never be used to test the model.

trans-unit.source: Fraction of test user ratings for training
trans-unit.target: Fraction of test user ratings for training

trans-unit.source: You can specify that some portion of the user ratings you have collected be used for training.
trans-unit.target: You can specify that some portion of the user ratings you have collected be used for training.

trans-unit.source: Fraction of cold users
trans-unit.target: Fraction of cold users

trans-unit.source: Cold users are users that the system has not previously encountered.
trans-unit.target: Cold users are users that the system has not previously encountered.

trans-unit.source: Typically, because the system has no information on these users, they are valuable for training, but predictions might be less accurate.
trans-unit.target: Typically, because the system has no information on these users, they are valuable for training, but predictions might be less accurate.

trans-unit.source: Fraction of cold items
trans-unit.target: Fraction of cold items

trans-unit.source: Cold items are items that the system has not previously encountered.
trans-unit.target: Cold items are items that the system has not previously encountered.

trans-unit.source: Because the system has no information about these items, they are valuable for training, but predictions might be less accurate.
trans-unit.target: Because the system has no information about these items, they are valuable for training, but predictions might be less accurate.

trans-unit.source: Fraction of ignored users
trans-unit.target: Fraction of ignored users

trans-unit.source: The recommender splitter can ignore some users, which enables you to train the model on a subset of data.
trans-unit.target: The recommender splitter can ignore some users, which enables you to train the model on a subset of data.

trans-unit.source: This might be useful for performance reasons.
trans-unit.target: This might be useful for performance reasons.

trans-unit.source: Use this option to specify the percentage of ignored users.
trans-unit.target: Use this option to specify the percentage of ignored users.

trans-unit.source: Fraction of ignored items
trans-unit.target: Fraction of ignored items

trans-unit.source: The recommender splitter can ignore some items and train the model on a subset of data.
trans-unit.target: The recommender splitter can ignore some items and train the model on a subset of data.

trans-unit.source: This might be useful for performance reasons.
trans-unit.target: This might be useful for performance reasons.

trans-unit.source: Use this option to specify the percentage of ignored items.
trans-unit.target: Use this option to specify the percentage of ignored items.

trans-unit.source: Remove occasionally produced cold items
trans-unit.target: Remove occasionally produced cold items

trans-unit.source: An item is said to be "occasionally cold" if it is covered only by the test set and it wasn't explicitly chosen as cold.
trans-unit.target: An item is said to be "occasionally cold" if it is covered only by the test set and it wasn't explicitly chosen as cold.

trans-unit.source: Such items can be produced by steps (4) and (6) in the algorithm described in the <legacyLink xlink:href="#algorithm" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">How Recommender Data is Split</legacyLink> section.
trans-unit.target: Such items can be produced by steps (4) and (6) in the algorithm described in the <legacyLink xlink:href="#algorithm" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">How Recommender Data is Split</legacyLink> section.

trans-unit.source: The anticipated use of this option is that the requested number of cold users and items is set to zero.
trans-unit.target: The anticipated use of this option is that the requested number of cold users and items is set to zero.

trans-unit.source: This ensures that all entities in the test set are included in the training set.
trans-unit.target: This ensures that all entities in the test set are included in the training set.

trans-unit.source: Random seed for recommender
trans-unit.target: Random seed for recommender

trans-unit.source: You can specify a seed if you want to split the data the same way every time.
trans-unit.target: You can specify a seed if you want to split the data the same way every time.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, by default the input data is randomly split.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, by default the input data is randomly split.

trans-unit.source: Regular Expression Options
trans-unit.target: Regular Expression Options

trans-unit.source: Regular expression
trans-unit.target: Regular expression

trans-unit.source: Type an expression.
trans-unit.target: Type an expression.

trans-unit.source: Based on the regular expression you provide, the dataset is divided into two sets of rows: rows with values that match the expression and all remaining rows.
trans-unit.target: Based on the regular expression you provide, the dataset is divided into two sets of rows: rows with values that match the expression and all remaining rows.

trans-unit.source: The regular expression is applied only to the specified column in the dataset.
trans-unit.target: The regular expression is applied only to the specified column in the dataset.

trans-unit.source: Also, regular expressions can be applied only to columns that contain string data types.
trans-unit.target: Also, regular expressions can be applied only to columns that contain string data types.

trans-unit.source: For more information about composing regular expressions, see the <externalLink><linkText>MSDN library</linkText><linkUri>https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/kweb790z(v=vs.110).aspx</linkUri></externalLink>, or this Wikipedia article: <externalLink><linkText>Regular Expressions</linkText><linkUri>http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regular_expressions</linkUri></externalLink>
trans-unit.target: For more information about composing regular expressions, see the <externalLink><linkText>MSDN library</linkText><linkUri>https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/kweb790z(v=vs.110).aspx</linkUri></externalLink>, or this Wikipedia article: <externalLink><linkText>Regular Expressions</linkText><linkUri>http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regular_expressions</linkUri></externalLink>

trans-unit.source: Relative Expression
trans-unit.target: Relative Expression

trans-unit.source: Relational expression
trans-unit.target: Relational expression

trans-unit.source: Type an expression that performs a mathematical comparison.
trans-unit.target: Type an expression that performs a mathematical comparison.

trans-unit.source: The expression divides the dataset into two sets of rows: rows with values that meet the condition, and all remaining rows.
trans-unit.target: The expression divides the dataset into two sets of rows: rows with values that meet the condition, and all remaining rows.

trans-unit.source: The expression can be applied only to the specified column.
trans-unit.target: The expression can be applied only to the specified column.

trans-unit.source: Note the following restrictions when using relative expressions to split a dataset:
trans-unit.target: Note the following restrictions when using relative expressions to split a dataset:

trans-unit.source: Relative expressions can be applied to any columns that contain a numeric data type.
trans-unit.target: Relative expressions can be applied to any columns that contain a numeric data type.

trans-unit.source: Relative expressions can reference a maximum of one column name.
trans-unit.target: Relative expressions can reference a maximum of one column name.

trans-unit.source: In relative expressions, use the ampersand character (&) for the AND operation and use the pipe character (|) for the OR operation.
trans-unit.target: In relative expressions, use the ampersand character (&) for the AND operation and use the pipe character (|) for the OR operation.

trans-unit.source: The following operators are allowed for relative expressions: <, >, <=, >=, ==, !=
trans-unit.target: The following operators are allowed for relative expressions: <, >, <=, >=, ==, !=

trans-unit.source: You cannot group operations by using "(" and ")".
trans-unit.target: You cannot group operations by using "(" and ")".

trans-unit.source: More Examples
trans-unit.target: More Examples

trans-unit.source: You can see examples of how the <ui>Split</ui> module is used by exploring these sample experiments in the <externalLink><linkText>Model Gallery</linkText><linkUri>http://gallery.azureml.net/</linkUri></externalLink>:
trans-unit.target: You can see examples of how the <ui>Split</ui> module is used by exploring these sample experiments in the <externalLink><linkText>Model Gallery</linkText><linkUri>http://gallery.azureml.net/</linkUri></externalLink>:

trans-unit.source: In the sample, <externalLink><linkText>Cross Validation for Binary Classification: Adult Dataset</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=525734</linkUri></externalLink>, a 20% sampling rate is applied to create a smaller randomly sampled dataset.
trans-unit.target: In the sample, <externalLink><linkText>Cross Validation for Binary Classification: Adult Dataset</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=525734</linkUri></externalLink>, a 20% sampling rate is applied to create a smaller randomly sampled dataset.

trans-unit.source: (The original census dataset had over 30,000 rows; the training dataset has around 6500).
trans-unit.target: (The original census dataset had over 30,000 rows; the training dataset has around 6500).

trans-unit.source: The dataset is cleaned for missing values and then passed to five different models for training and cross-validation.
trans-unit.target: The dataset is cleaned for missing values and then passed to five different models for training and cross-validation.

trans-unit.source: In the sample, <externalLink><linkText>Cross Validation for Regression</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=525735</linkUri></externalLink>, the data is randomly and evenly assigned to five folds (with no stratification), and the results are passed to <link xlink:href="75fb875d-6b86-4d46-8bcc-74261ade5826" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Cross-Validate Model</link>.
trans-unit.target: In the sample, <externalLink><linkText>Cross Validation for Regression</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=525735</linkUri></externalLink>, the data is randomly and evenly assigned to five folds (with no stratification), and the results are passed to <link xlink:href="75fb875d-6b86-4d46-8bcc-74261ade5826" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Cross-Validate Model</link>.

trans-unit.source: As a result, cross-validation will build and test 5 models on subsets of the data, rather than the 10 folds created by default if <link xlink:href="a8726e34-1b3e-4515-b59a-3e4a475654b8" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Partition and Sample</link> is not used beforehand.
trans-unit.target: As a result, cross-validation will build and test 5 models on subsets of the data, rather than the 10 folds created by default if <link xlink:href="a8726e34-1b3e-4515-b59a-3e4a475654b8" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Partition and Sample</link> is not used beforehand.

trans-unit.source: The sample, <externalLink><linkText>Split Partition and Sample</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=525948</linkUri></externalLink>, demonstrates multiple ways to use partitioning and sampling.
trans-unit.target: The sample, <externalLink><linkText>Split Partition and Sample</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=525948</linkUri></externalLink>, demonstrates multiple ways to use partitioning and sampling.

trans-unit.source: Initially, sampling is applied to get only 10% of the rows from the larger Census dataset.
trans-unit.target: Initially, sampling is applied to get only 10% of the rows from the larger Census dataset.

trans-unit.source: Next, the <ui>Assign to Folds</ui> option is used to assign rows in the dataset to one of three groups that are evenly sized.
trans-unit.target: Next, the <ui>Assign to Folds</ui> option is used to assign rows in the dataset to one of three groups that are evenly sized.

trans-unit.source: The <legacyBold>Income</legacyBold> column is used as the key column for stratification, meaning that each group will be evenly sampled for income.
trans-unit.target: The <legacyBold>Income</legacyBold> column is used as the key column for stratification, meaning that each group will be evenly sampled for income.

trans-unit.source: The final <ui>Partition and Sample</ui> module specifies which fold to draw data from for the successive <ui>Split</ui> operation.
trans-unit.target: The final <ui>Partition and Sample</ui> module specifies which fold to draw data from for the successive <ui>Split</ui> operation.

trans-unit.source: Technical Notes
trans-unit.target: Technical Notes

trans-unit.source: The following requirements apply to all uses of <ui>Split</ui>:
trans-unit.target: The following requirements apply to all uses of <ui>Split</ui>:

trans-unit.source: This module requires a dataset that contains at least two rows as input.
trans-unit.target: This module requires a dataset that contains at least two rows as input.

trans-unit.source: Generally speaking, the output dataset should not match the input dataset, even if all inputs are the same.
trans-unit.target: Generally speaking, the output dataset should not match the input dataset, even if all inputs are the same.

trans-unit.source: If you use the option for a stratified split, the output datasets can be further divided by the specified subgroups.
trans-unit.target: If you use the option for a stratified split, the output datasets can be further divided by the specified subgroups.

trans-unit.source: These are specified by selecting a strata column.
trans-unit.target: These are specified by selecting a strata column.

trans-unit.source: If you use the option to specify the desired number of rows, the specified number must be a positive integer, and the number must be less than the total number of rows in the dataset.
trans-unit.target: If you use the option to specify the desired number of rows, the specified number must be a positive integer, and the number must be less than the total number of rows in the dataset.

trans-unit.source: If you specify a number as a percentage, or if you use a string that contains the "%" character, the value is interpreted as a percentage.
trans-unit.target: If you specify a number as a percentage, or if you use a string that contains the "%" character, the value is interpreted as a percentage.

trans-unit.source: All percentage values must be within the range (0, 100), not including the values 0 and 100.
trans-unit.target: All percentage values must be within the range (0, 100), not including the values 0 and 100.

trans-unit.source: If you specify a number or percentage that is a floating point number less than one, and you do not use the percent symbol (%), the number is interpreted as a proportional value.
trans-unit.target: If you specify a number or percentage that is a floating point number less than one, and you do not use the percent symbol (%), the number is interpreted as a proportional value.

trans-unit.source: How Rows are Apportioned during Stratified Random Sampling
trans-unit.target: How Rows are Apportioned during Stratified Random Sampling

trans-unit.source: If you use stratified random sampling to ensure that your datasets are balanced for a target attribute, all the input rows are first grouped (stratified) by the values in the column you select as <legacyBold>Strata Column</legacyBold>, and then shuffled within each group.
trans-unit.target: If you use stratified random sampling to ensure that your datasets are balanced for a target attribute, all the input rows are first grouped (stratified) by the values in the column you select as <legacyBold>Strata Column</legacyBold>, and then shuffled within each group.

trans-unit.source: Finally, the rows from each group are selectively apportioned to the output datasets, according to the specified ratio.
trans-unit.target: Finally, the rows from each group are selectively apportioned to the output datasets, according to the specified ratio.

trans-unit.source: How Recommender Data is Split
trans-unit.target: How Recommender Data is Split

trans-unit.source: The following algorithm is used when splitting data into training and test sets for use with a recommendation model:
trans-unit.target: The following algorithm is used when splitting data into training and test sets for use with a recommendation model:

trans-unit.source: The requested fraction of ignored items is removed with all associated observations.
trans-unit.target: The requested fraction of ignored items is removed with all associated observations.

trans-unit.source: The requested fraction of cold items is moved to the test set with all associated observations.
trans-unit.target: The requested fraction of cold items is moved to the test set with all associated observations.

trans-unit.source: The requested fraction of ignored users that remain after the first two steps is removed with all associated observations.
trans-unit.target: The requested fraction of ignored users that remain after the first two steps is removed with all associated observations.

trans-unit.source: The requested fraction of cold users that remain after the first two steps is moved to the test set with all associated observations.
trans-unit.target: The requested fraction of cold users that remain after the first two steps is moved to the test set with all associated observations.

trans-unit.source: The requested fraction of training-only users that remain after the first two steps is moved to the training set with all associated observations.
trans-unit.target: The requested fraction of training-only users that remain after the first two steps is moved to the training set with all associated observations.

trans-unit.source: For each user that remains after all the previous steps, the requested fraction of test user ratings for training is moved to the training set, and the remainder is moved to the test set.
trans-unit.target: For each user that remains after all the previous steps, the requested fraction of test user ratings for training is moved to the training set, and the remainder is moved to the test set.

trans-unit.source: At least one observation is always moved to the training set for each user.
trans-unit.target: At least one observation is always moved to the training set for each user.

trans-unit.source: If requested, instances that are associated with the occasionally produced cold items can be removed from the test set.
trans-unit.target: If requested, instances that are associated with the occasionally produced cold items can be removed from the test set.

trans-unit.source: An item is said to be "occasionally cold" if it is covered only by the test set, and it wasn't explicitly chosen as cold.
trans-unit.target: An item is said to be "occasionally cold" if it is covered only by the test set, and it wasn't explicitly chosen as cold.

trans-unit.source: Such items can be produced by steps (4) and (6).
trans-unit.target: Such items can be produced by steps (4) and (6).

trans-unit.source: The anticipated use of this option is that the requested number of cold users and items is set to zero.
trans-unit.target: The anticipated use of this option is that the requested number of cold users and items is set to zero.

trans-unit.source: This ensures that all entities in the test set are included in the training set.
trans-unit.target: This ensures that all entities in the test set are included in the training set.
